header.title: Pagan Prayers
header.category: Comparative Religious Texts / Anthology of Spiritual Practices

central_thesis: Marah Ellis Ryan's 'Pagan Prayers' compiles a diverse array of ancient and indigenous prayer traditions, aiming to illuminate the beauty and cultural significance of non-Western and pre-Abrahamic spiritual literature. The anthology implicitly argues for the recognition and value of these often-overlooked texts, presenting them as sophisticated expressions of human engagement with the divine, comparable to more commonly known Western rituals and philosophies.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the book's purpose: to showcase the rich and often-destroyed aboriginal literature of Ancient America and other 'primitive' peoples, asserting their beauty and spiritual depth. It highlights the oral tradition of Apache and Navajo prayers, contrasting them with Mexican fragments salvaged from historical destruction.

structure_content.chapter_title: On the Writing of a Prayer of Praise (Mexican)
structure_content.summary: A poetic reflection on the sacred act of writing and the inherent beauty of creation, likening a 'song' or written work to precious jewels. It emphasizes the harmony found in natural elements (mist, rainbow) and ritual objects (turquoise bells, silver drum).

A direct invocation to a creative deity, praised as 'Lord of Charms' and 'Illustrious,' who grants life to the dead and is merciful. The prayer seeks the deity's continued tenderness, protection, and the perpetual worship of the Accadian people, asserting the deity's role as mankind's creator.

A petitionary prayer addressed to Stenatlihan, the supreme sky goddess, primarily seeking a long life, physical well-being ('good looks,' 'good breath,' 'good speech'), and divine guidance. It expresses a communal desire for goodness and shared prosperity, portraying a harmonious relationship between the supplicant and others.

An extensive and descriptive invocation to a male sky deity, emphasizing its dwelling places (house of Dawn, evening twilight, dark cloud, rains, mist, peace) and attributes (rainbow path, zig-zag lightning, dark cloud moccasins/headdress). The liturgy focuses on drawing the deity's presence and power, particularly through atmospheric phenomena, and concludes with a request for healing and restoration after a sacrifice, leading to a state of beauty and peace.

A concise hymn recognizing the unparalleled greatness of the supreme deity in both heavenly and earthly realms. It highlights the profound respect and submission commanded by the deity's voice, causing lesser gods and genii to prostrate.

A poignant plea for the soul of a dying individual, asking for their connection to Heaven and noting their weakening state. It invokes Ishtar, the Moon God's daughter, who descends from her mountain dwelling to intervene. The prayer's resolution anticipates an ascent to the Sun-god for the soul's reception into holy hands, emphasizing purification and radiance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Babylonian Prayer for Health (Exorcism of Spirits of Disease) (Chaldean)
structure_content.summary: A structured exorcistic prayer divided into tablets, targeting various 'noxious spirits' associated with illness and malevolent influences (e.g., neck-spirits of desert/mountains/sea/morass/city, evil images, cruel head-spirits). It repeatedly invokes 'Spirit of Heaven, remember! Spirit of Earth, remember!' and calls upon Nin-cigal and Nebs to redirect harmful spirits and imbue propitious ones for the sick man's recovery, strength, and life from the Sun-god and Merodach.

A petition to the Sun, who is seen as a divine agent sent by the great god Hea, to direct humanity, cast rays of peace, and cure suffering. The supplicant confesses shortcomings and transgressions, offering food and a victim, asking for pardon and recovery for a 'King,' and seeking guidance for the magician.

A powerful invocation to the Sun, revered for its position in the 'high heavens' and its power to illuminate lands and transcend boundaries. The incantation praises the Sun's ability to 'annihilate falsehood,' dissipate evil influences (wonders, omens, sorceries, dreams, apparitions), and foil malicious designs. It seeks refuge in the Sun's presence and asks for protection against spell-makers, for inner joy, and for divine direction.

An invocation to Amit-abha and Sakya-muni, and the 'omnipotent and omniscient Holy Spirit,' requesting their compassionate presence to draw near and receive offerings. The liturgy emphasizes communal recitation and the descent of divine entities.

A formal imperial declaration informing celestial and terrestrial spirits (sun, moon, planets, stars, clouds, seas, rivers) of an upcoming ceremony to honor Shang-Ti. It requests the spirits to exert their power and communicate the Emperor's desire to Shang-Ti, acknowledging Shang-Ti as the benevolent creator of matter, light, and protector of humanity.

structure_content.chapter_title: Prayer of Transformation into a Lotus (Egyptian)
structure_content.summary: A prayer of identification and petition, addressing the lotus as a divine form (type of Nefer-Temu). The speaker, asserting knowledge of the underworld gods, asks for a place in Amentet and the ability for the soul to move freely and not be driven away from the company of gods after death.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Prayer for Preservation of the Heart (Egyptian)
structure_content.summary: A vital post-mortem prayer for the heart, the essence of existence, to ensure it faces no opposition in judgment or separation from the great god of Amentet. It invokes Osiris, the gods of the divine clouds, and seeks 'fair words' for the deceased 'Auf-ankh' to prosper. The prayer includes explicit instructions for its ritual use with a basalt scarab.

A hymn of profound praise for Amun-Ra, extolling him as the 'Lord of the thrones of the earth,' 'oldest existence,' 'ancient of heaven,' and 'support of all things.' He is venerated as the chief of gods, lord of truth, creator of all, deliverer of the oppressed, judge of the poor, and the 'sleepless' one whose goodness brings joy to gods.

A blessing intended for scattered seeds, invoking the mighty Ukko and the 'Daughters of Creation' for nourishment and protection. It calls upon the Earth to 'unlock her treasures' and nourish the young seeds, ensuring the prolific strength of nature is sustained.

An invocation to Panu, the God of fire and child of the Sun-mother, asking for the fire to be lifted to the sky, placed within the 'golden ring' and 'rock of copper,' to shine by day and rest by night. This hymn embodies a reverence for fire as a primal, divine element tied to the sun's cycle.

A philosophical exhortation to embrace the present moment ('To-day') as the essence of life, recognizing 'Yesterday' as a dream and 'To-morrow' as a vision. It champions 'The Bliss of Growth,' 'The Glory of Action,' and 'The Splendor of Beauty' found in living the current day fully, influencing the past and future.

An adoration of Buddha as the 'Victor over the hosts of evil' and the 'all-wise Being,' who is perfect and glorified. The prayer humbly asks Buddha to descend to the world, pour blessings, and be gracious from his 'heavenly world,' recognizing him as the eternal redemption for all creatures.

An imploration to Agni, the divine priest and 'best giver of wealth,' to bring the gods and grant 'glorious wealth of vigorous kindred.' Agni, revered as the illuminator of darkness and guarder of law, is asked to be gracious and remain for the supplicant's welfare, receiving offerings that reach the gods.

A visceral and desperate prayer addressed to dice, personified as intoxicating and powerful entities. The gambler describes the ruinous yet alluring hold of the 'brown dice,' confessing his inability to resist their call and asking for their mercy and for their 'wrath' to abate, redirecting their power away from him.

A reverent adoration directed towards the great god of Ise, other branch kami, and Sohodo no kami. The prayer humbly seeks correction for 'unwitting faults' and asks for blessings and favor to guide the supplicant in performing 'good works in the Way,' highlighting respect for divine powers and moral conduct.

A lyrical and melancholic prayer from a singer who finds solace and inspiration in flowers, dreaming of songs of beauty. Despite a sense of sorrow ('place of tears'), the singer calls for rejoicing, acknowledging the brevity of earthly life, and resolves to seek and bring forth beautiful songs and fragrant flowers, ultimately seeking 'a place of joy.'

A dramatized ceremonial dialogue between priests and Tla-loc, the God of Storms. Priests announce Tla-loc's appearance and call to devotees to seek him in his 'cloudy house.' Tla-loc asserts his divine return and power over dangers, challenging those who 'affront' him, and declaring himself a 'terrible god' whose voice resounds on the winds.

A praise to Teteo-inan, the 'Mother of Gods' and 'Heart of the Earth,' venerating her as the source of life and abundance. She is depicted as blooming yellow flowers, scattering seeds, shining like a butterfly, feeding wild beasts, and providing green herbs and fish, embodying the generative and nurturing aspects of the divine feminine.

structure_content.chapter_title: Prayer to the Mexican God of Fire (Mexican)
structure_content.summary: A ritualistic prayer from a 'Victim' who descends into the 'Hall of Flame' (a volcano crater) via a sacred rope, aiming to avoid shame for ancestors. Priests and devotees encourage the 'magician' to sing, calling upon the 'Woman with Abundant Hair' (Mist and Rain) for intervention, culminating in the appearance of the god to bring rain.

A ceremony involving a masked high priest personating Kin-teotl, the god of maize. The priest speaks of the 'flower in his heart' and Kin-teotl's birth 'from the water,' a 'glorious god.' An altar priest expresses earthly love, while flutes sound, and a goddess figure is carried to the 'mart,' startling the priest's heart. The prayer ends with a call to sleep, seeking joy.

A powerful hymn dedicated to Cihua-Coatl, the 'Serpent Woman' and mythic mother of earth-born people. She is described as plumed with eagle feathers, beating her drum from the 'Place of the Old,' embodying both the goddess of fields and a fierce goddess of war who supports and protects her people, appearing 'adorned in the ancient manner.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Prayer to the God of Thieves (South Pacific Island)
structure_content.summary: A practical prayer for success in plunder, addressed to the divine Outre-reter and Kongo. It explicitly asks these deities to cause everything in a target house—the owner, threshold, insects, central post, ridge-pole, rafters, and thatch—to fall asleep, thereby enabling the act of thievery.

A devotional invocation to Ormazd, the 'giver, forgiver, rich in love,' revered as the eternal and supreme ruler. The supplicant expresses thanks, accepts good deeds, believes in pure law, and seeks forgiveness for sins, striving for mental and moral purity. The ultimate goal is to enter Paradise and avoid hell, praising Ormazd as the Overseer who rewards good.

A profound philosophical adoration of the 'Soul of the Soul,' emphasizing the unknowable and incomprehensible essence of the divine. It asserts that neither human thought, reason, nor intellect can grasp the deity's attributes or existence, which remains a hidden secret beyond worldly perception, despite its imprint on all beings.

A poignant and deeply personal prayer from the aging King of Cusco to the Creator. He pleads not to be forgotten in death, questioning the Creator's identity and nature ('phantom, a thing that causes fear'), and expressing a longing for knowledge of the divine, acknowledging his old age and humble origins from earth and clay.

An earnest invocation to the 'Ruler,' 'Lord of the universe,' 'Lord of reproduction,' 'Lord of divination,' and 'Creator of the world.' The prayer expresses a profound yearning to comprehend this omnipresent yet elusive deity, whose presence is questioned ('Where art thou?'), and for whom the supplicant's 'eyes fail... for the sole desire to know thee.'

key_concepts.definition: Direct address, invocation, or petition to deities, spirits, or cosmic forces from pre-Christian, non-Abrahamic, or autochthonous spiritual traditions. These prayers reveal diverse methods of spiritual engagement, from adoration and thanksgiving to specific requests for health, prosperity, protection, or guidance in death.

The practice of honoring and appealing to specific gods, goddesses, or spirits, each with distinct domains, attributes, and roles (e.g., Stenatlihan as sky goddess, Agni as fire god, Tla-loc as storm god, Ishtar as a helper in dying). The effectiveness of prayer often relies on addressing the appropriate entity.

Prayers are often presented as integral components of larger ceremonial structures, including sacrifices, offerings, exorcisms, dramatized performances (e.g., Mexican Tla-loc and Fire God ceremonies), and rites for the deceased. These contexts provide a framework for the 'operative' side of spiritual work.

The various methods and techniques employed across traditions to interact with the spiritual realm, achieve desired outcomes, or navigate existential states. Prayer, invocation, magical incantation, and specific ritual actions (like using a basalt scarab or making a sacrifice) are understood as tools within these spiritual technologies.

The prayers often reflect a sophisticated understanding of their respective cosmologies, referencing heavens, earth, underworlds (e.g., Amentet), and the interplay of natural phenomena (clouds, mist, rain, sun, moon, stars) as divine manifestations or domains.

The recurring theme of the supplicant's relationship with the divine, ranging from humble adoration and gratitude to urgent pleading for intervention, acknowledgment of shortcomings, and a deep desire for knowledge or connection with the transcendent.

Beyond the individual prayers, the compiler's overarching objective to collect and present these texts serves as an act of cultural preservation, particularly for traditions that have been suppressed or destroyed, thereby offering material for contemporary spiritual exploration and academic study.

practical_system.description: This book is an anthology rather than a single, cohesive practical magical system. However, the collected prayers implicitly outline various practical spiritual approaches and operative mechanisms from diverse cultures. It demonstrates how different societies engaged with deities and spirits for specific outcomes, revealing foundational elements that can be adapted or studied by modern practitioners. The texts themselves serve as templates for invocation, petition, and communion, illustrating the magical power inherent in spoken or written word when directed with intent.
tools: Sacred objects/images (e.g., basalt scarab set in gold for Egyptian heart preservation, dice as objects of prayer/influence in Hindu Gambler's prayer).
Offerings (e.g., food, victims in Chaldean/Mexican prayers, symbolic flowers in Mexican prayers).
Ritual implements (e.g., rope for descent in Mexican Fire God ceremony, drums in Cihua-Coatl hymn, flutes in Mexican Maize prayer).
Natural elements/phenomena as divine manifestations or targets of prayer (e.g., clouds, mist, rain, sun, moon, stars in Navajo, Chinese, Finnish prayers).
Shrines and altars as focal points for spiritual contact (e.g., Japanese Kami-Dana, Mexican Maize prayer).
Smoke (implicitly in Navajo Liturgy with prepared smoke for sacrifice).
The voice/song of the supplicant or priest as a powerful medium (e.g., Mexican Singer's prayer, Mexican Fire God ceremony).
rituals: Invocation and direct address to deities (e.g., Accadian, Apache, Navajo, Chaldean, Hindu, Mexican, Peruvian).
Petitionary prayer for specific needs: health, long life, prosperity, protection, successful crops, and guidance in death (e.g., Apache, Navajo, Babylonian, Egyptian, Finnish).
Sacrifice and offerings as a means of communion and appeasement (e.g., Navajo, Chaldean Prayer to the Sun, Mexican God of Fire, Chinese Liturgy).
Exorcism or banishment of noxious spirits and harmful influences (Babylonian Prayer for Health, Chaldean Magical Incantation).
Veneration and adoration, often expressed through hymns of praise (e.g., Assyrian, Egyptian Amun-Ra, Hindu Buddha, Persian Ormazd, Mexican All-Mother).

Transformative prayers or rites for the soul's journey, including post-mortem navigation and spiritual integration (e.g., Egyptian Lotus Transformation, Egyptian Heart Preservation, Assyrian Prayer for the Dying).
Dramatized ceremonies involving priests, victims, or specific roles, often incorporating symbolic actions (e.g., Mexican Tla-Loc, Mexican God of Fire, Mexican Maize Prayer).
Ritual actions involving physical objects and intentions (e.g., 'fastening a rope to the sacred tree' in Mexican Fire God prayer, placing a basalt scarab in Egyptian Heart Preservation).
Prayers for specific illicit outcomes, demonstrating practical applications of spiritual manipulation (e.g., South Pacific God of Thieves prayer to induce sleep).

relevant_quotes.text: This little book of thoughts big, and thoughts childish, goes to the reader with the hope that it bears the little known fact that Ancient America had a written aboriginal literature much of which was beautiful.
I unwind my song! I unwind my song like a string of jewels, all precious.
With clouds dark, your mind en veloping, come to us!

May naught stand up to oppose me in judgment; may there be no opposition to me in the presence of the sovereign princes; may no evil be wrought against me in the pres- ence of the gods; may there be no parting of thee from me in the presence of the great god, the lord of Amentet.
These dice hook, prick, undo, burn and inflame. After the gift of childish playthings they ruin the winner; yet to the gambler they are covered with honey.
My eyes fail me for longing to see thee For the sole desire to know thee.

critical_analysis.relevance: Marah Ellis Ryan's 'Pagan Prayers' holds significant relevance for Western Esotericism and Occultism as a unique anthology of primary source material on historical and indigenous spiritual technology. While not a grimoire or a prescriptive magical manual, it offers invaluable comparative insight into the diverse forms of invocation, petitionary prayer, and deity veneration across various ancient cultures. For practitioners of Chaos Magic, Hermeticism, or eclectic magical traditions, this collection provides a rich tapestry of cultural blueprints for interacting with the numinous, designing personal rituals, and understanding the energetic currents associated with different pantheons and cosmic forces. The included texts demonstrate practical applications such as exorcism (Babylonian), transformation (Egyptian), seeking specific outcomes (Navajo for health, South Pacific for plunder), and navigating liminal states (Assyrian and Egyptian death prayers). It underscores the universal human impulse to connect with and influence spiritual realms, presenting a de-Westernized perspective on ritual practice that can inform and inspire contemporary magical workings.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This book is primarily aimed at scholars of comparative religion, anthropology, and ancient history, as well as general readers interested in world spiritual traditions. From an esoteric and occult perspective, its target audience expands to include practitioners of modern paganism, reconstructionist polytheism, eclectic magicians, ritual designers, and anyone seeking to deepen their understanding of historical prayer forms and their potential application within a broader magical context. It is also valuable for those challenging a solely Abrahamic or Eurocentric view of spiritual practice, offering diverse cultural models of engagement with the divine.
